hook.text: A company held a town hall to announce change. No Q&A was allowed. Trust dropped 30% overnight.

buildup.text: One-way communication broadcasts the plan. Two-way communication builds buy-in.

discovery.text: People who can ask questions, challenge, and be heard are far more likely to commit to the outcome.

twist.text: Listening doesn't mean agreeing. But the act of listening communicates respect and earns commitment.

climax.text: Build feedback loops: town halls with Q&A, skip-levels, anonymous channels. Listen publicly and respond.

punchline.text: Broadcast creates awareness. Dialogue creates commitment.

quiz.question: Why is two-way communication essential during change?
options: People who can ask questions and be heard are more likely to commit
One-way announcements are always sufficient for organizational change
Listening to employee concerns only slows down the change process
